title: TRAVEL: The Grand Canyon is awe-inspiring
text:

I HAVE never felt as insignificant and small as I did when I visited the Grand Canyon. 
The seemingly never-ending desert and blue sky was almost suffocating. 
I stood looking over the edge of the cliff, posing many philosophical questions about the universe that unfortunately were never answered. 
And as I looked around, hoping people didn't think I was too weird, I noticed others doing the same, in between posing for photos. 
Visiting the Grand Canyon seemed to be a very emotional experience for people (me included) and the heat definitely amplified this. 
Seeing the Grand Canyon for the first time is definitely the dictionary definition of awe: "solemn wonder tinged with latent fear". 
Being overwhelmed by the sheer beauty and vastness of this iconic spot is all part of the experience and something you will never forget. 
The first time I saw the Grand Canyon I was flying above it in a helicopter with a small group in 2012. Kristy Muir 
I had taken the joy flight from the quaint township of Boulder because I was time-poor and it was the fastest way to see it. 
But it definitely was not the cheapest way to check it out, nor the best. 
Getting a bird's eye view of the area was incredible, although the actual ride was not my cup of tea - it was the middle of a hot summer's day and I was surrounded by glass. 
I chose the cheapest package which meant I missed out on landing and having a champagne picnic, one kilometre below the rim of the canyon. 
Which is why, when I visited the Grand Canyon again, this time with my boyfriend, I opted to go by road and explore the area on foot. 
The journey from Las Vegas to the Grand Canyon, via the iconic Route 66, is long and hot, but worth every second. AIN'T IT GRAND?: Sunshine Coast Daily journalist Kristy Muir with her boyfriend Lion Goldsworthy. 
We went during the peak-tourist season, and met so many great people, but for those wanting a solitary experience, the herds of people are not ideal. About five million people visit the Grand Canyon every year, most of them in summer. 
On average, the canyon in reaches about 30 degrees along the South Rim and 39C at the bottom. 
The canyon's heat is extremely dangerous and signs alert you to the number of people who die of heat and thirst hiking the canyon every year. 
About 12 people die each year at the canyon, an average of two or three deaths per year are from falls over the rim, as per the park date from May. 
The Grand Canyon is the full package, with ravishing visual beauty; physical challenge (should you so desire); historic and cultural depth (American Indian split-twig figures found at the canyon are older than Stonehenge); and that rarest of experiences - a genuine encounter with the sublime. 
It is not hard to see why the Grand Canyon took three to six million years to form. 
And its contours are still changing because of erosion. 
My tips for anyone thinking about travelling to this natural wonder of the world - do your research, wear good walking shoes and have all the essential equipment for a hike. 
Grand Canyon by numbers Park statistics show that almost five million people visit the Grand Canyon each year and an average of 12 people die there annually. An average of two or three deaths per year are from falls over the rim. 
Data: May 1, 2015
